knowledge_graph.description: Isaac Asimov was a prolific Russian-American author and biochemistry professor at Boston University. He's considered one of science fiction's "Big Three" writers, alongside Arthur C. Clarke and Robert A. Heinlein. Asimov's 53-year career (1939-1992) produced 40 novels, 383 short stories, and over 280 non-fiction books. He's best known for his Foundation series (1951-1953) and robot stories, which explored the relationship between humans and machines. +1MoreLess

related_questions.question: What is Isaac Asimov famous for?
related_questions.snippet: One of the most prolific writers of his day, Asimov is known not only for his innovative science fiction—which has introduced readers to unforgettable characters, places, philosophies, and social commentaries—but also for the range of work he published during his lifetime: a children's book, a mystery novel, a humorous ...
related_questions.title: Isaac Asimov | EBSCO Research Starters

related_questions.question: What are the three laws of Asimov?
related_questions.snippet: A robot may not injure a human being or, through inaction, allow a human being to come to harm. A robot must obey orders given it by human beings except where such orders would conflict with the First Law. A robot must protect its own existence as long as such protection does not conflict with the First or Second Law.
related_questions.title: Isaac Asimov's "Three Laws of Robotics"

related_questions.question: What was Asimov's famous quote?
related_questions.snippet: Never let your sense of morals prevent you from doing what is right.
related_questions.title: Isaac Asimov - Quotes - Forbes

related_questions.question: What did Isaac Asimov die of?
related_questions.snippet: His HIV status was kept secret out of concern that the anti-AIDS prejudice might extend to his family members. He died in Manhattan on April 6, 1992, and was cremated. The cause of death was reported as heart and kidney failure.
related_questions.title: heart and kidney failure
